thread.title: Another building in the capital closes for structural repairs
thread.title_full: Another building in the capital closes for structural repairs

author: Brad Flahive
title: Another building in the capital closes for structural repairs
text:
Another building in the capital closes for structural repairs BRAD FLAHIVE Last updated 14:02, February 17 2017 CAMERON BURNELL/FAIRFAX NZ 
More invasive testing has been ordered for about 80 buildings in Wellington's CBD. 
The building used as the New Zealand Fire Service national headquarters has been partly closed while structural repairs are carried out. 
A number of floors were shut on Friday following an engineers assessment which has affected the fire service, and the Medical Council of New Zealand. 
According to a recorded voice message at the Medical Council, the building will be closed until Tuesday. Brad Flahive 
80 The Terrace closed for structural repairs. 
The building is one of about 80 in Wellington's CBD ordered by Wellington City Council to do more invasive testing in the wake of the Kaikoura earthquake. 
READ MORE: 
It is owned by Mt Everest Properties Ltd, and in 2015 the building was given an earthquake strengthening award for a retrofit seismic strengthening solution to an office tower. Supplied 
Wellington office building 80 The Terrace is owned by Mt Everest Properties. 
Paul McGill, Fire Service Deputy National Commander, said they were given verbal advice from the buildings engineers on Thursday that remediation work was required in building. 
"We are still waiting to receive a full report from the building engineers. In the meantime we are taking a cautious approach and have asked all National Headquarters staff to work from home or remotely as best they can. 
"Our ability to respond to emergency incidents is unaffected and the national response to the Port Hills fire is now being supported from Region 3 Headquarters at Wellington City Station." 
Mt Everest Properties could not be reached for comment.
